# Tagging Penguins

.bql[
.bold[Are	metal	tags	detrimental	to	penguins?]	A study looked at the 10 year survival rate of penguins tagged either with a metal tag or an electronic tag.  20% of the 167 metal tagged penguins survived, compared to 36% of the 189 electronic tagged penguins.
]



.pull-left-60[
<br>
.bqt.font90[
Is there a statistically discernible difference in survival rates?
\begin{align*}
H_0: p_M=p_E \quad H_A: p_M \neq p_E
\end{align*}
$p=$ true survival rate
]
]

.pull-right-40[
<center>
<img src="images/day18-1.jpg" width="65%" height="60%"> <br>
</center>
]


.footnote[Source: Saraux, et. al. (2011).  “Reliability of flipper-banded penguins as indicators of climate change,” Nature, 469, 203-206.]

---

class: middle

# Tagging Penguins

.pull-left[
.hljs[
20% of the 167 metal tagged penguins survived, compared to 36% of the 189 electronic tagged penguins.  
]
]

.pull-right[
|  | Survived | Died | Total |
| :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- |
| Metal Tag | 33 | 134 | 167 |
| Electronic Tag | 68 | 121 | 189 |
| Total | 101 | 255 | 356 |
]


.bqt.font80[
Are the conditions met for using the normal distribution for inference?

a).  Yes

b).  No
]

<br>
<details>
<summary>.red[Click for answer]</summary>
.hljs[The correct answer is a. With metal tags, 33 survived and 134 died.  With electronic tags, 68 survived and 121 died.  All counts are greater than 10.]
</details>

---

class: middle

# Pooled Proportion

.hljs[
We don't know $\mathrm{p}_{\mathrm{M}}$ or $\mathrm{p}_{\mathrm{E}}$, so how do we compute the SE for our hypothesis test?
]

.bql.font90[
- Assume the two proportions are equal and use .b[one proportion for both groups.]
- Our best guess of this one proportion comes from combining data from both groups and computing the overall proportion, called the .b[pooled proportion p.]
- .bold[Hint:] the pooled proportion will always be somewhere in between the two sample proportions.
]

---


class: middle

# Inference Using $\mathrm{N}(0,1)$


.bql[
If the distribution of the sample statistic is normal:
A confidence interval can be calculated by
\begin{align*}
\text { sample statistic } \pm z^* \times S E
\end{align*}
where $z^*$ is a $N(0,1)$ percentile depending on the level of confidence.
A p-value is the area in the tail(s) of a $N(0,1)$ beyond
\begin{align*}
z=\frac{\text { sample statistic }- \text { null value }}{\text { SE }}
\end{align*}
]


---



class: middle

# Test for a Difference in Proportions

.pull-left[
\begin{align*}
H_0: p_1&=p_2\\
H_a: p_1&\neq p_2\
\end{align*}
]

.pull-right[
\begin{align*}
\hat{p}_{pooled}=\frac{33+68}{167+189}=0.2837
\end{align*}


]


$$z=\frac{\left(\hat{p}_1-\hat{p}_2\right)-0}{\sqrt{\frac{\hat{p}_{pooled}(1-\hat{p}_{pooled})}{n_1}+\frac{\hat{p}_{pooled}(1-\hat{p}_{pooled})}{n_2}}}$$


If observed counts in the two-way table are at least 10, then the $p$-value can be computed as the area in the tail(s) of a standard normal beyond $z$. .out-t[Always use pooled proportion for the SE.]


---


class: middle

# Tagging Penguins

.bql[
20% of the 167 metal tagged penguins survived, compared to 36% of the 189 electronic tagged penguins.  
]
<br>
.bqt.font80[
33 survived with metal tags and 68 with electronic The pooled proportion is:
\begin{align*}
\hat{p}_{pooled}=\frac{33+68}{167+189}=0.2837
\end{align*}

SE for our test:
\begin{align*}
S E=\sqrt{\frac{0.284(1-.284)}{167}+\frac{0.284(1-.284)}{189}}=0.048
\end{align*}

]

---

class: middle

# Tagging Penguins

.bql[
20% of the 167 metal tagged penguins survived, compared to 36% of the 189 electronic tagged penguins.  The pooled SE is 0.048.
]

.hljs[
\begin{align*}
\text { Standardized test stat: } \quad z=\frac{(0.2-0.36)-0}{0.048}=-3.34
\end{align*}
]

.pull-left[

```{r}
# Standardized test statistic
((0.2 - 0.36) - 0)/(0.048)
```

]


.pull-right[
```{r}
# P-value
2*pnorm(-3.34,0,1)
```
]

--

.brand-red.b[Reject the null]

---

class: middle

# Tagging Penguins

.bql[
A difference in survival rates as extreme, or more extreme, than $16 \%$ would occur by chance only about $0.08 \%$ of the time. There is a statistically discernible difference $(\mathrm{z}=-3.34, \mathrm{p}=0.0008)$
]
<br>

.pull-left[
.bqt.font90[How much do the rates differ?
- Compute a $95 \%$ CI for the difference... 
]
]

.pull-right[
.bqt.font90[How do we compute the SE?
- We .b[can't] use the pooled version since we've concluded the proportions differ!
]
]

---

class: middle

# Confidence Interval for $p_1-p_2$


.hljs[
For large enough $\mathrm{n}_1$ and $\mathrm{n}_2$ : $\quad$ statistic $\pm \quad z^* \times S E$
]

$$\left(\hat{p}_1-\hat{p}_2\right) \pm z^* \sqrt{\frac{\hat{p}_1\left(1-\hat{p}_1\right)}{n_1}+\frac{\hat{p}_2\left(1-\hat{p}_2\right)}{n_2}}$$

---

class: middle

# Metal Tags and Penguins


.hljs[
$20 \%$ of the 167 metal tagged penguins survived, compared to $36 \%$ of the 189 electronic tagged penguins. Give a $90 \%$ confidence interval for the difference in proportions (metal - electronic).
]

.bql.font80[
What is $\mathrm{z}^*$ for the confidence interval?

a) 1.280

b) 1.645

c) 1.960

d) 2.575

e) 0.90
]



---

class: middle

# Tagging Penguins: 90% C.I

.hljs[
$20 \%$ of the 167 metal tagged penguins survived, compared to $36 \%$ of the 189 electronic tagged penguins. Give a $90 \%$ confidence interval for the difference in proportions (metal - electronic).
]


$90 \% C I$ for $\mathrm{p}_M-\mathrm{p}_E:$

\begin{align*}
(0.2-0.36) &\pm 1.645 \cdot \sqrt{\frac{0.2(1-0.2)}{167}+\frac{0.36(1-0.36)}{189}}\\
&=-0.16 \pm 1.645 \times 0.047\\
&=(-0.237,-0.09)
\end{align*}


.bqt.font90[
We are $90\%$ confident that the survival rate is between $9%$ and $23.7%$ lower for metal tagged penguins, as opposed to electronically tagged.
]




---


class: middle

# Metal Tags and Penguins


.hljs[
$20 \%$ of the 167 metal tagged penguins survived, compared to $36 \%$ of the 189 electronic tagged penguins. Give a $95 \%$ confidence interval for the difference in proportions (metal - electronic).
]

.bql.font80[
What is $\mathrm{z}^*$ for the confidence interval?

a) 1.280

b) 1.645

c) 1.960

d) 2.575

e) 0.90
]



---


class: middle

# Tagging Penguins: 95% C.I


.hljs[
$20 \%$ of the 167 metal tagged penguins survived, compared to $36 \%$ of the 189 electronic tagged penguins. Give a $95 \%$ confidence interval for the difference in proportions (metal - electronic).
]



$95 \% C I$ for $\mathrm{p}_M-\mathrm{p}_E:$

\begin{align*}
(0.20-0.36) &\pm 1.96 \sqrt{\frac{0.20 \times 0.80}{167}+\frac{0.36 \times 0.64}{189}}\\
&=-0.16 \pm 1.96 \times 0.047\\
&=(-0.251,-0.069)
\end{align*}


.bqt.font90[
We are $95 \%$ confident that between $6.9 \%$ to $25.1 \%$ fewer penguins survive when metal tags are used compared to electronic tags.
]
